<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module4_mcq_q100')" data-correct-answer="C">
  <strong style="display: block;">
  Some CFOs argue that CAPM-based discount rates should be adjusted upward whenever management feels uncertainty is “too high,” even if the project’s beta is correctly estimated. Why is this inconsistent with CAPM theory?
  </strong>

  <label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q100" value="A"> A. Because CAPM already adjusts for all forms of uncertainty, including idiosyncratic risk.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q100" value="B"> B. Because raising the discount rate reduces NPV mechanically, biasing project evaluation.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q100" value="C"> C. Because CAPM links expected return only to systematic (market) risk via beta; subjective uncertainty should not alter the discount rate.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q100" value="D"> D. Because WACC already reflects the tax-adjusted cost of financing.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q100" value="E"> E. Because the equity risk premium changes automatically when uncertainty rises.</label><br>
</form>

<div id="feedback-module4_mcq_q100" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: C. CAPM states that only systematic risk matters. Adding “extra” adjustments for perceived uncertainty double-counts risk and violates the model.
